title: odd mid-century script
content:
what is this insane thing? and is the L actually part of the face? it doesn't even really match.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425030411im_/http:/typophile.com/files/lustre_5093.jpg)
author: patricking

comments.content: [Holly Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425030411/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/urw/holly_script_ot_std_urw/?sample_text=Lustre&sample_size=144&acs_ss=-1&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1) is very similar with a cap 'L' that matches only slightly better.
Ahh, it looks like they gave the 'L' a bit of a squash and a [squoosh](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425030411/http:/typophile.com/wiki/squoosh).
huh. crazy. i actually like it better squashed. more, um, refrigerator-y.

is this type? or is it a piece of lettering?  
i have some samples of upright script with capitals quite different from the lower case. i think this was something of a trend in its day. perhaps the L could match somewhat more with the lowercase, but i always like this kind of effect.
